awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Survey and Analysis of the Angolan Herpetofauna
awd_abstract_narration:
Angola is among the largest countries in Africa, and its landscapes vary from arid desert to equatorial rainforest. This landscape diversity results in high, but poorly documented, levels of biodiversity in many groups, including amphibians and reptiles. This project will increase understanding of the diversity and evolution of Angola's amphibians and reptiles by analyzing species' distributions, abundances, genetics, and anatomy. Based on these data, undocumented species will be identified, characterized and formally described. Two major hypotheses will be tested: whether arid-adapted species of S.W. Angola are descended from East African ancestors that migrated during periods of dry climate, and whether species restricted to the Angolan highlands are ancient descendants of formerly widespread ancestors. Researchers will also test how climate factors affect the degree to which malaria-causing parasites specialize on particular lizard species. This project will also train students in field and laboratory methods, as well as data dissemination and analysis. Public outreach efforts will include development of short video documentaries and English- and Portuguese-language guides to Angola's amphibians and reptiles.

Surveys of the Angolan herpetofauna will be informed by current knowledge gained from the less than 8,000 specimens that currently exist in museums worldwide. A total of six expeditions throughout Angola will be undertaken over a period of three years, with each focusing on a region identified as poorly sampled based on the provenance of extant museum specimens or as key sampling areas for addressing taxonomic problems. Specimens obtained in survey efforts will be subjected to collection and analysis of ecological, genetic, and morphological data. Molecular systematic analyses of the genetic data will identify cryptic species and targeted high-throughput sequencing will be used to test biogeographic hypotheses. Morphological data collection will include external morphological examination as well as high-resolution CT scanning to identify diagnostic internal anatomical features of species under study. Ecological niche modeling of species' ranges will be used to explore patterns of faunal turnover and identify conservation priorities. All biodiversity data generated in the course of the project, including point localities, DNA sequences, and CT scans, will be made available to the broader scientific community. Results of the research will be disseminated in numerous publications focused on taxonomic revision, biogeography, morphological diversity, and/or parasite evolutionary ecology of the Angolan herpetofauna.

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
This project significantly increased our knowledge of the diversity and evolutionary history of the amphibians and reptiles of Angola, a sub-Saharan African country situated at the meeting point of arid southwestern Africa and tropical central Africa. We collected new samples from throughout western Angola; genetic and morphological data from these samples were used to document variation within Angola and broader relationships to the amphibians and reptiles in other areas of central and southern Africa. We discovered new species of lizards, frogs, and snakes, and amassed new distributional data for many other species, increasing the known diversity of the country. Project results have been disseminated in 28 peer-reviewed scientific publications (as of 2021), numerous conference presentations, and have been applied to IUCN conservation assessments. Scientific publications generated under this project include those focused on species descriptions, phylogenetic relationships, morphological evolution, surveys of protected areas, and syntheses of historical data. Collectively, our studies emphasized the high level of endemism characterizing the Angolan Escarpment, and identified several pervasive biogeographic patterns. These patterns include arid southwestern Angola harboring previously unrecognized diversity and endemism with links to adjacent Namibia, relationships of many central Angolan species to lineages farther east, and the presence of a unique set of species in the isolated Serra da Neve mountain. New phylogenetic studies clarified evolutionary relationships for many African amphibian and reptile groups, and were applied to study the evolution of morphological traits, such as the evolution of egg-eating adaptations in the skulls of Prosymna snakes. At the University of Michigan-Dearborn, an undergraduate-focused institution, nine undergraduate students were trained with the support of this project, including eight women. As of 2021, five former UM-Dearborn undergraduates have co-authored publications under this project. One Master's student and one postdoctoral researcher were also trained. Work performed at the University of Michigan-Dearborn complemented efforts at collaborating institutions Villanova University and the University of Florida. DNA sequencing work led by the University of Michigan-Dearborn has produced the first available genetic data for many African species and is publicly deposited in Genbank. Field work led by Villanova University generated preserved scientific specimens and associated tissue samples for >1,000 specimens of >110 species in >50 genera of amphibians and reptiles deposited in the California Academy of Sciences, the Florida Museum of Natural History, and the Instituto Nacional da Biodiversidade e Areas de Conservacao (INBAC) in Luanda, Angola. CT-scanning data generated by the University of Florida is publicly available via MorphoSource. The project developed capacity of biodiversity scientists in Angola through training in research methods and made new distributional data available for applications in local management.

 


Last Modified: 09/08/2021
Modified by: Matthew Heinicke
